title: EVE V Review: The Crowdsourced Alternative To Microsoft's Surface
description: This video brought to you by Squarespace. Start your free trial today at  to get 10% off your first purchase.   [EVE V REVIEW]  When I first heard about the Eve V, I saw it as just another Microsoft Surface lookalike and quickly forgot it. But when I was offered a chance to review it I looked into Eve again  and found a company trying to do in the PC space what OnePlus has done in smartphones. Namely: build something powerful, price it affordably, and give users a voice in the process. Im MrMobile and this is the first crowdsourced computer Ive ever used; join me for the Eve V review!   [LINKS]  Eve V [Eve-Tech]:   Eve V Hands-on [Windows Central]:   Intel Y-Series vs U-Series [Windows Central]:    [SUBSCRIBE]     [ABOUT MRMOBILE'S EVE V REVIEW]  MrMobile's Eve V review was produced following two weeks with an Eve V review device provided by Eve-Tech. The Eve V review sample was a pre-production device in the Core i5/8GB configuration and required a re-install of Windows 10 Home to fix a keyboard error (which did not solve the issue). Eve-Tech has promised to provide a replacement keyboard for further testing; if it solves the problem it will be reported in the comments.  This video sponsored by Squarespace.   [MUSIC]  True Persistence by Cymatix, available at Premium Beat:    Sensational by Cymatix, available at Premium Beat:    [SOCIALIZE]         [DISCLOSURE]  This post may contain affiliate links. See Mobile Nations' disclosure policy for more details:
transcript: - [Mr. Mobile] When I first heard about the Eve V, I saw it as just another Microsoft Surface lookalike and quickly forgot about it. But then a couple weeks ago, when I was offered a chance to review one, I looked into it again. And behind it, I found a company trying to do in the PC space what OnePlus has done in smartphones. Namely, build something powerful, price it affordably, and give users a voice in the process. I'm Mr. Mobile, and this is the first crowdsourced computer I've ever used. Join me for the Eve V review brought to you by Squarespace. (upbeat electronic music) If you've ever seen a Microsoft Surface, you already know what the V looks like. From the tablet body to the flip-out kickstand to the snap-on keyboard, this is familiar territory. But pick it up and you'll notice that it's almost 20% heavier than the Surface Pro and about 1/2 millimeter thicker, not counting the keyboard. That makes the V a clunker of a tablet, but Eve says that's the way the users wanted it. You know how every time a manufacturer makes a thinner phone, people say they'd actually prefer a thicker one if it lasted longer? Well, same deal here. The added depth of the V makes room for a 48-watt-hour battery. Still, that's just a hair bigger than the 45 watt-hours on the new Surface Pro, and in my couple weeks of testing, I've found it lasts long enough to get me through a workday but without much to spare after that. The community also wanted a lot of I/O, so the V packs two USB-C ports, one of them Thunderbolt 3; a headphone jack; one USB-A port per side; and a micro SD slot under the hinge. There's a fingerprint sensor in the power key that works well, and speakin' of keys, every version of the V includes the keyboard in the box. It's fully covered in Alcantara. I last saw that on the Surface laptop, but here it's even softer, more velvety, which makes for comfy keystrokes but also means it picks up every crumb and speck on every table there is. The keys themselves are great. They have a ton of travel, a backlight whose color you can change on the fly, and there's even a little Easter egg on the backspace key. I was surprised to see how many people were criticizing this in the comments of other reviews. Sure it's a little hokey, but to me, it's also a refreshing dash of personality that most machines lack. Oh, and to further set it apart from the Surface, the keyboard packs a built-in battery and Bluetooth, so it doesn't need to stay attached to the tablet to keep working. Before we get to everyday usage, let's talk specs. You've got your option of Intel Core i7, i5, and m3 CPUs, but these are the Y-series processors. They can only match the power of the heavier U-series for short bursts, and there's a trade-off in graphics power too. But the Y-series was designed for power efficiency. It has the benefit of not requiring a fan to keep it cool, and even my Core i5 review unit has little trouble keeping up with the writing and research part of my workload. If you wanna better understand the differences between the Intel Y- and U-series, I will link you to the Windows Central article that helped me out. (upbeat electronic music) Using the V for a couple weeks has given enough time for the honeymoon phase to wear off, so, first, let's talk about what's held on it. The color and brightness of the IGZO LCD are excellent, the built-in speakers are loud, the microphone array is elaborate, the glass trackpad is one of the smoothest I've used, and the absence of almost any branding is refreshing. Now for the flip side. The hinge design is not the most elegant, and the end of the kickstand is quite sharp. Neither of the cameras is very good, the speakers are lacking in bass, the bezels are pretty big, and there's a significant light-bleed problem too. That's the kinda thing I'm not too surprised to see on a device built to undercut the big guys. Ditto for the loose USB-C connector on both tablet and charging brick. Oh, and you may have noticed this connection error popping up on the video? Oh, that's because my review device consistently refused to connect with its keyboard, even after I reinstalled Windows. That was very frustrating, and problems like those can turn into big annoyances if you feel like you're not being heard when you report them. But here, the V is an example of crowdfunding gone right. Eve maintains a community in which its employees are active, including the company's own CEO, who shares his phone number with users to help pin down problems. It's really kinda cool. At least one of those problems, the loose USB connection, is apparently being addressed in the March 2018 production run, and I haven't seen anyone else reporting the kind of keyboard problems I've had. Eve tells me my review device is from a preproduction run, for what that's worth. While good customer service won't completely allay your fears when ordering a computer from such a small company, the savings might. Versus the Surface Pro, we're talkin' a difference of up to nearly $900 at the high end. Down at the entry level, which I frankly never recommend, the prices are closer to parity. But remember that the V includes the keyboard and the pen right in the box, which is a $230 savings over the Surface right there. So the Eve V is a very good value, and it gets a lot more right than I would have expected from a crowdsourced PC developed by a small company. But I probably wouldn't buy one for myself. While my keyboard problem was quite uncommon, and the support I received was topnotch, it made me think about what would happen if I were a regular customer having a similar problem. I wouldn't be able to just walk into a Microsoft store or Best Buy to get it repaired or replaced. That's life when you buy from boutique companies; I get it. And if that's worth the savings to you, then by all means, get in on the next flash sale. As for me, well, I'll bring it back to OnePlus again. It wasn't until the third generation of that phone that I really got onboard with the idea. And back here with Eve, I think I'll wait for the second generation of V to see what this company can do after a little more refinement. (upbeat electronic music) This video is brought to you by Squarespace. I bet you didn't know it, but we at Mobile Nations have a few sites built on Squarespace. They're fresh, they're flexible, and if anything ever goes wrong, we get 24/7/365 customer support. You can build one too, whether you're an artist, a musician, designer, anything. Click on through to Squarespace.com/MrMobile for 10% off your first purchase. And, hey, if there's something missing from my site that you'd like to see added, let me know in the comments. We'll see what we can do. Meantime, get your own site started. The link in the description. Squarespace.com/MrMobile. That's gonna do it for this one, folks. For more reviews of laptops, smartphones, wearables, and even an electric car from time to time, be sure to subscribe to theMrMobile on YouTube. Until next time, thanks for watching. And stay mobile, my friends. (upbeat electronic music)
